p: Ebola virus disease (EVD) is a lethal, infectious hemorrhagic fever that occurs in outbreaks in equatorial Africa [ 1]. The 2014â€“2016 West Africa epidemic was the largest to date, claiming the lives of over 11,000 people [ 2]. The second largest outbreak in history currently spreads through eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) since it began on 1 August 2018, in the North Kivu Province. Unlike past successfully contained outbreaks in the DRC, the current outbreak is relentless, despite intensive efforts toward case detection, contact tracing and management, safe and dignified burials, and ring vaccination. As of 10 July 2019, there have been a total of 2357 confirmed cases and 1553 confirmed deaths [ 3].
